canonical_explanation.text: Hydrogen is the lightest and most abundant element in the universe (atomic number 1, electronic configuration 1s¹). It occupies a unique position in the periodic table because it resembles both alkali metals (Group 1: one valence electron, forms H⁺ cation, electropositive) and halogens (Group 17: one electron short of noble gas configuration, forms H⁻ hydride ion, exists as diatomic molecule H₂). Hydrogen has three isotopes: protium (¹H, no neutrons, most abundant ~99.98%), deuterium (²H or D, one neutron, ~0.02%), and tritium (³H or T, two neutrons, radioactive with t₁/₂ ≈ 12.33 years). Dihydrogen (H₂) can be prepared by the action of dilute acids on metals (Zn + H₂SO₄ → ZnSO₄ + H₂↑), electrolysis of water, reaction of metals with water or alkali (2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂), Bosch process (CO + H₂O → CO₂ + H₂ using Fe₂O₃-Cr₂O₃ catalyst at 673 K), Lane process using steam over red-hot iron, and the steam-reforming process (CH₄ + H₂O → CO + 3H₂ using Ni catalyst at 1270 K). Dihydrogen is a colourless, odourless, highly combustible gas (burns in air: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O). It reacts with halogens, nitrogen (Haber process: N₂ + 3H₂ → 2NH₃), and metal oxides (used as a reducing agent). Hydrides are classified as ionic/saline (formed by s-block metals except Be and Mg, e.g., NaH, CaH₂ — crystalline, high m.p., conduct electricity when molten, react with water: NaH + H₂O → NaOH + H₂), covalent/molecular (formed by p-block elements, e.g., CH₄, NH₃, H₂O, HF — volatile, low m.p. and b.p., can be electron-rich like NH₃, electron-precise like CH₄, or electron-deficient like B₂H₆), and metallic/interstitial (formed by d-block and f-block metals, e.g., TiH₁.₇, PdH₀.₇ — non-stoichiometric, hydrogen occupies interstitial sites in the metal lattice, good conductors, used in hydrogenation catalysis). Water (H₂O) has a bent structure with bond angle 104.5° due to two lone pairs on oxygen. It has anomalously high boiling point (373 K) due to extensive intermolecular hydrogen bonding. Water is amphoteric (acts as both acid and base). Hard water contains dissolved Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ salts: temporary hardness is due to bicarbonates Ca(HCO₃)₂/Mg(HCO₃)₂ (removed by boiling or Clark's method — adding Ca(OH)₂), permanent hardness is due to chlorides and sulphates (removed by washing soda Na₂CO₃, Calgon's method Na₆P₆O₁₈, ion exchange resins, or distillation). Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) is prepared by acidification of barium peroxide (BaO₂ + H₂SO₄ → BaSO₄ + H₂O₂), electrolysis of 50% H₂SO₄, and industrially by the anthraquinone auto-oxidation process. H₂O₂ has an open-book (non-planar) structure with a dihedral angle of 111.5° (gas phase). It acts as both an oxidising agent (stronger tendency: H₂O₂ + 2H⁺ + 2e⁻ → 2H₂O) and a reducing agent (H₂O₂ → O₂ + 2H⁺ + 2e⁻). Decomposition: 2H₂O₂ → 2H₂O + O₂ (catalysed by MnO₂, finely divided metals, light). It is used as a bleaching agent, disinfectant, rocket propellant (90% H₂O₂), in pollution control, and as a hair bleach. Its strength is expressed in terms of volume strength (e.g., 10-volume H₂O₂ liberates 10 volumes of O₂ per volume of H₂O₂ at STP).
rules: Hydrogen resembles alkali metals (1 valence electron, forms H⁺) and halogens (1 electron short of duplet, forms H⁻, exists as H₂).
Three isotopes: protium (¹H), deuterium (²H or D), tritium (³H or T, radioactive).
Lab preparation: Zn + dil. H₂SO₄ → ZnSO₄ + H₂↑; industrial: steam reforming of methane or Bosch process.
Ionic hydrides: formed by s-block (except Be, Mg), high m.p., conduct when molten, react vigorously with water.
Covalent hydrides: electron-deficient (B₂H₆), electron-precise (CH₄), electron-rich (NH₃, H₂O, HF — have lone pairs).
Metallic/interstitial hydrides: non-stoichiometric, formed by d- and f-block metals, H occupies interstitial sites.
Water: bent shape (104.5°), high b.p. due to H-bonding, amphoteric nature.
Temporary hardness (bicarbonates): removed by boiling or Ca(OH)₂; permanent hardness (Cl⁻/SO₄²⁻ salts): removed by Na₂CO₃, Calgon, or ion exchange.
H₂O₂ has a non-planar open-book structure with dihedral angle 111.5°.
H₂O₂ acts as both oxidising and reducing agent; decomposes to H₂O + O₂ catalysed by MnO₂.
Volume strength of H₂O₂: '10 volume' means 1 mL of H₂O₂ solution gives 10 mL of O₂ at STP.
D₂O (heavy water) is used as a moderator in nuclear reactors.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen resembles alkali metals because it:

options.text: Has a high electronegativity like fluorine
Has one electron in its valence shell and can form a univalent cation (H⁺)
Exists as a diatomic molecule like chlorine
Forms hydrides with metals like NaH where hydrogen is the anion

questions.explanation_correct: Like alkali metals (Li, Na, K, etc.), hydrogen has one electron in its outermost shell (1s¹) and can lose it to form a univalent cation H⁺. This electronic configuration similarity places hydrogen in Group 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Existing as a diatomic molecule and forming hydride ions (H⁻) are properties that make hydrogen resemble halogens, not alkali metals. Hydrogen's electronegativity (2.1) is intermediate, not as high as fluorine (4.0).

questions.question_text: Which of the following isotopes of hydrogen is radioactive?
questions.explanation_correct: Tritium (³H or T) is the only radioactive isotope of hydrogen. It has one proton and two neutrons, making its nucleus unstable. It undergoes β-decay with a half-life of approximately 12.33 years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protium (¹H, no neutrons) and deuterium (²H, one neutron) are both stable isotopes. Only tritium, with two neutrons, has an unstable nucleus and exhibits radioactivity.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen resembles halogens because it:

options.text: Forms a univalent cation by losing one electron
Has metallic lustre in its solid state
Exists as a diatomic molecule and can gain one electron to form H⁻ (hydride ion)
Has very high ionisation enthalpy like noble gases

questions.explanation_correct: Like halogens, hydrogen exists as a diatomic molecule (H₂, similar to Cl₂, Br₂) and requires only one electron to achieve a noble gas configuration (helium). It can gain one electron to form the hydride ion H⁻, analogous to Cl⁻, Br⁻.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Forming a univalent cation (H⁺) is the property that makes hydrogen resemble alkali metals, not halogens. Hydrogen does not have metallic lustre, and its ionisation enthalpy (1312 kJ/mol), while high, is a separate consideration.

questions.question_text: The atomic mass ratio of deuterium to protium is approximately 2:1. Which physical property would show the LARGEST difference between H₂O and D₂O?
questions.explanation_correct: D₂O (heavy water) has a boiling point of 101.4°C compared to 100°C for H₂O. The greater mass of deuterium leads to stronger intermolecular forces (due to lower zero-point vibrational energy), causing measurably higher boiling point, melting point, and density. This is the most noticeable physical difference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both H₂O and D₂O are colourless liquids with the same bent molecular structure. Both are poor electrical conductors in pure form. The boiling point difference, though small (1.4°C), is the most significant and measurable physical property difference among the options listed.

questions.question_text: Heavy water (D₂O) is extensively used as:

options.text: A coolant in thermal power plants
A moderator in nuclear reactors to slow down neutrons
A solvent for electrolysis in the chlor-alkali process
A reagent for synthesising tritium in the laboratory

questions.explanation_correct: D₂O (heavy water) is used as a moderator in nuclear reactors (e.g., CANDU and Indian PHWRs). Deuterium atoms effectively slow down fast neutrons to thermal energies through elastic collisions without absorbing them significantly, sustaining the fission chain reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ordinary water is used as a coolant in thermal power plants. The chlor-alkali process uses brine (NaCl solution), not D₂O. D₂O is not a standard reagent for tritium synthesis. Its primary industrial use is as a neutron moderator in nuclear reactors.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about hydrogen:
(i) Its ionisation enthalpy (1312 kJ/mol) is much higher than that of alkali metals.
(ii) It has a positive electron gain enthalpy, unlike halogens.
(iii) It can act as both an oxidising and a reducing agent.
Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statement (i) is correct: hydrogen's ionisation enthalpy (1312 kJ/mol) is much higher than alkali metals (e.g., Li: 520 kJ/mol). Statement (iii) is correct: hydrogen acts as a reducing agent (e.g., CuO + H₂ → Cu + H₂O) and as an oxidising agent (e.g., 2Na + H₂ → 2NaH). Statement (ii) is incorrect: hydrogen's electron gain enthalpy is negative (−73 kJ/mol), meaning it does release energy when gaining an electron, though less exothermic than halogens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (ii) is wrong. Hydrogen's electron gain enthalpy is negative (−73 kJ/mol), not positive. It can accept an electron to form H⁻, though less readily than halogens. Statements (i) and (iii) are both correct.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following pairs correctly represents hydrogen's dual resemblance?
(I) Like Na, hydrogen forms H⁺ ion; like Cl, hydrogen forms H⁻ ion.
(II) Like Na, hydrogen is a good conductor; like Cl, hydrogen is coloured.
questions.explanation_correct: Statement (I) correctly captures hydrogen's dual nature: like alkali metals (Na, K), hydrogen can lose its single valence electron to form H⁺; like halogens (Cl, Br), it can gain one electron to attain noble gas configuration and form H⁻. Statement (II) is wrong because hydrogen gas is a poor conductor and is colourless, unlike metallic sodium (good conductor) or coloured chlorine (greenish-yellow).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (II) is factually incorrect on both counts. Hydrogen is an insulator in gaseous form (not a conductor like Na), and it is colourless (chlorine is greenish-yellow, not hydrogen). Only statement (I) accurately describes hydrogen's dual resemblance.

questions.question_text: In the laboratory, dihydrogen is commonly prepared by the reaction of:
questions.explanation_correct: In the laboratory, dihydrogen is prepared by the reaction of granulated zinc with dilute sulphuric acid: Zn + H₂SO₄(dil.) → ZnSO₄ + H₂↑. Zinc is sufficiently reactive to displace hydrogen from dilute acids, and the reaction proceeds at a moderate, controllable rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper, silver, and gold are less reactive than hydrogen in the reactivity series and cannot displace hydrogen from dilute acids. Dilute HNO₃ is an oxidising acid that produces NO or NO₂ instead of H₂. Only zinc (or metals above hydrogen in the activity series) with dilute H₂SO₄ or HCl gives H₂.

questions.question_text: In the Bosch process for industrial production of dihydrogen, the water-gas shift reaction is:
questions.explanation_correct: The Bosch process involves the water-gas shift reaction: CO + H₂O → CO₂ + H₂, carried out at about 673 K using iron oxide-chromium oxide catalyst (Fe₂O₃-Cr₂O₃). CO from water gas (CO + H₂) is converted to CO₂, which is removed by washing with water under pressure, yielding pure H₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is the steam reforming of methane. Option C is the formation of water gas (syngas). Option D is electrolysis of water. The Bosch process specifically refers to the water-gas shift reaction where CO reacts with steam over a catalyst to produce CO₂ and H₂.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a property of dihydrogen gas?

options.text: It is the lightest known gas
It is a good supporter of combustion like oxygen
It is highly combustible and burns with a pale blue flame in air

questions.explanation_correct: Dihydrogen is not a supporter of combustion — it is itself combustible. A substance that supports combustion allows other things to burn in it (like O₂). Hydrogen burns in oxygen/air but does not support the combustion of other substances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D are all correct properties of dihydrogen. It is indeed the lightest gas (molar mass 2 g/mol), colourless and odourless, and highly combustible (burns in air to form water with a pale blue flame). Only option C is incorrect.

questions.question_text: When steam is passed over red-hot coke at 1270 K, the products obtained are:
questions.explanation_correct: When steam is passed over red-hot coke at about 1270 K, water gas is formed: C + H₂O → CO + H₂. This mixture of CO and H₂ is called water gas or synthesis gas (syngas). It is an important industrial feedstock for producing hydrogen and various chemicals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO₂ and H₂ would be the product of the water-gas shift reaction (Bosch process), not direct reaction with coke at high temperature. The primary products of steam over red-hot coke are CO and H₂ (water gas), not CO₂ + H₂O or CH₄ + O₂.

questions.question_text: Dihydrogen acts as a reducing agent when it reacts with heated CuO. The product(s) formed is/are:
questions.explanation_correct: When dihydrogen is passed over heated CuO, it reduces the metal oxide to the free metal: CuO + H₂ → Cu + H₂O. Hydrogen acts as the reducing agent (gets oxidised to H₂O), and CuO is reduced to metallic copper. This is a standard demonstration of hydrogen's reducing property.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper hydride (CuH₂) is not formed under these conditions. Cu₂O is not the final product since H₂ fully reduces CuO to Cu. Cu(OH)₂ would require aqueous conditions. The clean reduction product is metallic copper and water.

questions.question_text: In the steam reforming process for H₂ production, methane reacts with steam in the presence of a nickel catalyst at 1270 K. What is the molar ratio of H₂ to CO produced?
questions.explanation_correct: The steam reforming reaction is: CH₄ + H₂O →(Ni, 1270K) CO + 3H₂. For every mole of methane and steam consumed, one mole of CO and three moles of H₂ are produced, giving a H₂:CO molar ratio of 3:1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The balanced equation CH₄ + H₂O → CO + 3H₂ clearly shows 3 moles of H₂ per mole of CO. Ratios of 1:1, 2:1, or 4:1 do not satisfy the stoichiometry of this reaction.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following reactions:
(I) Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl₂ + H₂
(II) 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂
(III) Cu + H₂SO₄(dil.) → CuSO₄ + H₂
(IV) 2Al + 2NaOH + 2H₂O → 2NaAlO₂ + 3H₂
Which reactions correctly produce dihydrogen?
questions.explanation_correct: Reactions I, II, and IV all correctly produce dihydrogen. Zinc reacts with dilute HCl (I), sodium reacts with water (II), and aluminium dissolves in NaOH solution to form sodium aluminate and H₂ (IV). Reaction III is incorrect because copper is below hydrogen in the activity series and cannot displace hydrogen from dilute acids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reaction III is wrong. Copper (Cu) has a higher reduction potential than hydrogen and lies below hydrogen in the electrochemical/activity series. It cannot reduce H⁺ ions from dilute H₂SO₄ to form H₂. Copper reacts only with oxidising acids like concentrated H₂SO₄ or HNO₃, producing SO₂ or NOₓ, not H₂.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Dilute HNO₃ is not used for the laboratory preparation of H₂ even with reactive metals like zinc.
Reason: HNO₃ is an oxidising acid that oxidises the H₂ produced to water and itself gets reduced to NO or NO₂.

options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is NOT the correct explanation of Assertion
Assertion is true but Reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true and the Reason correctly explains the Assertion. HNO₃ is a strong oxidising acid. Even when reactive metals like Zn react with dilute HNO₃, the nascent hydrogen produced is immediately oxidised back to water by HNO₃, which itself is reduced to NO, NO₂, N₂O, or NH₃ depending on concentration. Hence HNO₃ cannot be used for H₂ preparation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Assertion is definitely true — HNO₃ is never used for H₂ preparation in the lab. The Reason accurately explains why: the oxidising nature of HNO₃ prevents H₂ gas from being evolved. Therefore, both are true and the Reason correctly explains the Assertion.

questions.question_text: Ionic (saline) hydrides are typically formed by:

options.text: p-block elements like carbon and nitrogen
d-block transition metals like iron and chromium
s-block elements (alkali and alkaline earth metals, except Be and Mg)
Noble gases like xenon and krypton

questions.explanation_correct: Ionic (saline) hydrides are formed by highly electropositive s-block elements — alkali metals (LiH, NaH, KH) and heavier alkaline earth metals (CaH₂, SrH₂, BaH₂). Beryllium and magnesium hydrides are predominantly covalent due to smaller size and higher charge density. These hydrides contain the H⁻ ion in a crystal lattice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: p-block elements form covalent (molecular) hydrides. d-block and f-block metals form metallic (interstitial) hydrides. Noble gases generally do not form hydrides. Only s-block metals (except Be and Mg) are electropositive enough to transfer electrons to hydrogen, forming true ionic hydrides.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of an electron-deficient hydride?
questions.explanation_correct: B₂H₆ (diborane) is an electron-deficient hydride because boron in BH₃ has only 6 electrons in its valence shell (lacks a complete octet). There are not enough electrons to form conventional 2-centre-2-electron bonds for all B–H connections, so B₂H₆ uses three-centre two-electron (3c-2e) banana bonds for its bridging hydrogens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NH₃ and H₂O are electron-rich hydrides (they have lone pairs available for donation). CH₄ is an electron-precise hydride (all bonding and non-bonding electrons exactly satisfy the octet). Only B₂H₆ has fewer electrons than required for conventional bonding, making it electron-deficient.

questions.question_text: When sodium hydride (NaH) is added to water, the products formed are:
questions.explanation_correct: Ionic hydrides react vigorously with water: NaH + H₂O → NaOH + H₂↑. The hydride ion (H⁻) from NaH acts as a strong base, abstracting a proton from water to form H₂ gas, while Na⁺ combines with OH⁻ to form NaOH. This reaction is highly exothermic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NaH does not produce Na₂O, H₂O₂, or O₂ when reacting with water. The H⁻ ion from the hydride reacts with H₂O in an acid-base reaction: H⁻ + H₂O → H₂ + OH⁻. The products are always NaOH and H₂.

questions.question_text: Metallic (interstitial) hydrides are characterised by which of the following properties?

options.text: They are stoichiometric compounds with definite formulae
They are non-stoichiometric, with hydrogen atoms occupying interstitial sites in the metal lattice
They are gaseous at room temperature with low boiling points
They are electrical insulators like ionic hydrides

questions.explanation_correct: Metallic (interstitial) hydrides are formed when hydrogen atoms occupy the interstitial positions in the crystal lattice of d-block and f-block metals. They are typically non-stoichiometric (e.g., TiH₁.₇₃, PdH₀.₇) because the number of interstitial sites occupied varies. They retain metallic conductivity and have metallic appearance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metallic hydrides are non-stoichiometric (not definite formula), solid (not gaseous), and good electrical conductors (not insulators). Their metallic character distinguishes them from both ionic and covalent hydrides.

questions.question_text: NH₃, H₂O, and HF are classified as electron-rich hydrides because they:

options.text: Have more bonding pairs than needed for stable bonding
Contain lone pairs of electrons on the central atom that can be donated
Have three-centre two-electron bonds like diborane
Are formed by metals and contain free electrons

questions.explanation_correct: Electron-rich hydrides have one or more lone pairs on the central atom beyond what is needed for bonding. NH₃ has one lone pair, H₂O has two lone pairs, and HF has three lone pairs. These lone pairs make them Lewis bases capable of donating electrons, forming coordinate bonds, and participating in hydrogen bonding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electron-rich hydrides have excess non-bonding electrons (lone pairs), not excess bonding pairs. Three-centre bonds are found in electron-deficient hydrides like B₂H₆. Electron-rich hydrides are molecular compounds of p-block elements, not metallic compounds with free electrons.

questions.question_text: Which of the following hydrides would conduct electricity when molten?
questions.explanation_correct: NaH is an ionic hydride composed of Na⁺ and H⁻ ions held in a crystal lattice. When melted, the ions become mobile and can conduct electricity. In fact, electrolysis of molten NaH liberates hydrogen at the anode, confirming the presence of H⁻ ions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CH₄, NH₃, and SiH₄ are covalent (molecular) hydrides with no ions. They remain as discrete molecules even when melted or dissolved, so they cannot conduct electricity. Only ionic hydrides like NaH, CaH₂, etc., conduct in the molten state.

questions.question_text: Consider the hydrides LiH, BeH₂, B₂H₆, CH₄, NH₃, H₂O, and HF. Which statement is correct?

options.text: LiH and BeH₂ are both ionic hydrides
B₂H₆ is electron-precise and CH₄ is electron-deficient
LiH is ionic; BeH₂ is covalent (polymeric); B₂H₆ is electron-deficient; CH₄ is electron-precise; NH₃, H₂O, HF are electron-rich
All hydrides from LiH to HF are covalent in nature

questions.explanation_correct: LiH is a true ionic hydride (Li⁺H⁻). BeH₂ is a covalent polymeric hydride (Be has high charge density, making the bonding predominantly covalent). B₂H₆ is electron-deficient (B lacks electrons for normal bonding). CH₄ is electron-precise (all electrons used in bonding, octet complete). NH₃ (1 lone pair), H₂O (2 lone pairs), and HF (3 lone pairs) are electron-rich hydrides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because BeH₂ is covalent, not ionic. Option B reverses the classification — B₂H₆ is electron-deficient and CH₄ is electron-precise. Option D is wrong because LiH is clearly ionic. Option C correctly classifies all the hydrides.

questions.question_text:
Among the following pairs, which is the correct comparison regarding hydrides of Group 1 and Group 17 elements?
(I) NaH is ionic with high melting point; HCl is covalent with low boiling point.
(II) Both NaH and HCl release H₂ when added to water.
questions.explanation_correct: Statement (I) is correct: NaH is an ionic compound (Na⁺H⁻) with a high melting point (638°C), while HCl is a covalent gas with a very low boiling point (−85°C). Statement (II) is incorrect: NaH reacts with water to release H₂ (NaH + H₂O → NaOH + H₂), but HCl simply dissolves in water to form hydrochloric acid (HCl → H⁺ + Cl⁻) without producing H₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (II) is wrong because HCl dissolves in water as an acid (forming H₃O⁺ and Cl⁻) and does not liberate H₂ gas. Only ionic hydrides like NaH release H₂ when reacted with water. Statement (I) correctly describes the ionic vs covalent nature of these hydrides.

questions.question_text: The bond angle in a water molecule is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Water has a bent (V-shaped) molecular geometry with a bond angle of approximately 104.5°. The oxygen atom is sp³ hybridised with two bonding pairs and two lone pairs. The lone pairs exert greater repulsion than bonding pairs, compressing the bond angle from the ideal tetrahedral angle of 109.5° to 104.5°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 90° would correspond to unhybridised p-orbitals. 109.5° is the ideal tetrahedral angle (as in CH₄) without lone pair compression. 120° is the trigonal planar angle. The two lone pairs on oxygen compress the H–O–H bond angle to 104.5°.

questions.question_text: Temporary hardness of water is caused by the presence of:
questions.explanation_correct: Temporary hardness is caused by dissolved bicarbonates (hydrogen carbonates) of calcium and magnesium: Ca(HCO₃)₂ and Mg(HCO₃)₂. It is called 'temporary' because it can be removed simply by boiling: Ca(HCO₃)₂ →(heat) CaCO₃↓ + H₂O + CO₂↑. The insoluble carbonate precipitates out.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorides and sulphates of Ca and Mg cause permanent hardness, which cannot be removed by boiling. Sodium and potassium salts do not cause hardness because their carbonates, chlorides, and sulphates are all soluble and do not interfere with soap.

questions.question_text: Water has an unusually high boiling point (100°C) compared to H₂S (−60°C) because of:

options.text: Extensive intermolecular hydrogen bonding in water
Ionic character of the O–H bond
Greater van der Waals forces in water

questions.explanation_correct: Water has an anomalously high boiling point due to extensive intermolecular hydrogen bonding. Each water molecule can form up to four hydrogen bonds (two as donor through H atoms, two as acceptor through lone pairs on O). This creates a strong three-dimensional hydrogen-bonded network requiring significantly more energy to break during boiling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water (M = 18) actually has a lower molecular mass than H₂S (M = 34), so molecular mass cannot explain the higher b.p. The O–H bond is polar covalent, not ionic. Van der Waals forces are weaker in water than H₂S (which is larger and more polarisable). Hydrogen bonding is the key factor.

questions.question_text: Which of the following methods can remove permanent hardness of water?
questions.explanation_correct: Permanent hardness (due to chlorides and sulphates of Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺) can be removed by adding washing soda (Na₂CO₃): CaCl₂ + Na₂CO₃ → CaCO₃↓ + 2NaCl and MgSO₄ + Na₂CO₃ → MgCO₃↓ + Na₂SO₄. The insoluble carbonates precipitate out, softening the water. Other methods include Calgon treatment and ion-exchange resins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boiling only removes temporary hardness (bicarbonates). Adding Ca(OH)₂ (Clark's method) removes only temporary hardness by converting bicarbonates to insoluble carbonates. Simple filtration through sand removes suspended particles but not dissolved ions causing hardness.

questions.question_text: In Clark's method of water softening, Ca(OH)₂ is added to hard water containing Ca(HCO₃)₂. The reaction that occurs is:
questions.explanation_correct: In Clark's method, a calculated amount of Ca(OH)₂ (slaked lime) is added to temporarily hard water: Ca(HCO₃)₂ + Ca(OH)₂ → 2CaCO₃↓ + 2H₂O. The soluble bicarbonate is converted to insoluble calcium carbonate, which precipitates out. This method is economical for large-scale water treatment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option D shows thermal decomposition (boiling), not Clark's method. Options B and C have incorrect stoichiometry or products. The correct balanced reaction shows 1 mole of Ca(HCO₃)₂ reacting with 1 mole of Ca(OH)₂ to give 2 moles of CaCO₃ and 2 moles of H₂O.

questions.question_text: Water acts as an amphoteric substance. Which pair of reactions demonstrates this?

options.text: H₂O + HCl → H₃O⁺ + Cl⁻ (acts as base); H₂O + NH₃ → NH₄⁺ + OH⁻ (acts as acid)
2H₂O → 2H₂ + O₂ (acts as acid); H₂O + Na → NaOH + H₂ (acts as base)
H₂O + CO₂ → H₂CO₃ (acts as acid); H₂O + NaOH → Na⁺ + OH⁻ + H₂O (acts as base)
H₂O → H⁺ + OH⁻ (acts as acid); H₂O + H₂O → H₂O₂ (acts as base)

questions.explanation_correct: Water's amphoteric nature is demonstrated by: (1) acting as a Brønsted base by accepting a proton from HCl: H₂O + HCl → H₃O⁺ + Cl⁻; and (2) acting as a Brønsted acid by donating a proton to NH₃: H₂O + NH₃ → NH₄⁺ + OH⁻. In the first reaction water is protonated, in the second it is deprotonated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B describes decomposition and a redox reaction, not acid-base behaviour. Option C incorrectly labels water as an acid when it reacts with CO₂ — water is actually the base/solvent. Option D shows autoionisation and an incorrect reaction (water does not form H₂O₂ by self-reaction). Only option A correctly shows water acting as both acid and base.

questions.question_text: Calgon (sodium hexametaphosphate, Na₆P₆O₁₈) removes permanent hardness of water by:

options.text: Converting Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ to insoluble phosphates that precipitate
Sequestering Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ ions as soluble complex anions [Ca₂(PO₃)₆]²⁻
Decomposing bicarbonates by supplying OH⁻ ions
Exchanging Na⁺ for Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ through ion exchange

questions.explanation_correct: Calgon (Na₆P₆O₁₈) is sodium hexametaphosphate. It ionises to give Na⁺ and the hexametaphosphate anion [P₆O₁₈]⁶⁻ (also written as (PO₃)₆⁶⁻). This anion sequesters Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ ions by forming soluble but non-ionisable complex anions: 2Ca²⁺ + (PO₃)₆⁶⁻ → [Ca₂(PO₃)₆]²⁻. Since Ca²⁺ is trapped in the complex, it no longer interferes with soap.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calgon does not precipitate calcium phosphate — it forms a soluble complex. It does not decompose bicarbonates (that is Clark's method). While Na⁺ ions are released, the mechanism is complexation/sequestration, not simple ion exchange as in resin-based methods.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the structure and properties of water is INCORRECT?

options.text: Ice has a less dense structure than liquid water because of the open cage-like arrangement of hydrogen bonds
Water has a high specific heat capacity, which moderates climate
Water reaches maximum density at 4°C because hydrogen bonds are completely broken at this temperature
Water is an excellent solvent for ionic compounds due to its high dielectric constant

questions.explanation_correct: The statement in C is incorrect. Water reaches maximum density at 4°C not because hydrogen bonds are completely broken, but because of a balance between two competing effects: (1) thermal expansion (which decreases density) and (2) collapse of the open ice-like hydrogen-bonded structure (which increases density). At 4°C the optimum balance is reached. Hydrogen bonds still exist extensively in liquid water at 4°C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is correct: ice has an open tetrahedral structure with more space between molecules, making it less dense than liquid water. Option B is correct: water's high specific heat (4.18 J/g·K) moderates climate. Option D is correct: water's high dielectric constant (80.1) reduces interionic attraction, making it an excellent solvent for ionic compounds.

questions.question_text: A sample of hard water contains both Ca(HCO₃)₂ and CaSO₄. To completely soften this water, the most effective single treatment would be:

options.text: Passing through an ion-exchange resin column
Simple distillation followed by adding Ca(OH)₂

questions.explanation_correct: An ion-exchange resin (e.g., Na₂R, where R = zeolite/resin) can remove both temporary and permanent hardness in a single treatment by exchanging Na⁺ for Ca²⁺: Na₂R + Ca²⁺ → CaR + 2Na⁺. Boiling removes only temporary hardness. Ca(OH)₂ removes only temporary hardness. Ion exchange or addition of Na₂CO₃ can handle both, but ion exchange is the most effective single treatment for water containing both types of hardness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boiling removes only temporary hardness (bicarbonates), leaving CaSO₄ behind. Ca(OH)₂ (Clark's method) converts bicarbonates to carbonates but does not remove sulphates. Distillation followed by Ca(OH)₂ is unnecessarily complicated — if you distill, the water is already pure. Ion exchange handles both types efficiently.

questions.question_text: The structure of hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) is best described as:

options.text: Linear, with all atoms in a straight line
Planar, with all atoms in the same plane
Non-planar, open-book structure with a dihedral angle

questions.explanation_correct: H₂O₂ has a non-planar open-book (gauche) structure. The two O–H bonds are not in the same plane as the O–O bond. The dihedral angle (angle between the two H–O–O planes) is 111.5° in the gas phase and about 90° in the solid state. This non-planar structure arises due to repulsion between lone pairs on the two oxygen atoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₂O₂ is neither linear nor planar. The lone pairs on each oxygen atom create repulsion that forces the two O–H bonds out of the O–O–H plane, resulting in a skewed (open-book) structure. A tetrahedral geometry does not apply to a molecule with only four atoms arranged around two centres.

questions.question_text: H₂O₂ acts as an oxidising agent in which of the following reactions?
questions.explanation_correct: In the reaction H₂O₂ + 2KI → 2KOH + I₂, H₂O₂ oxidises I⁻ to I₂. The oxidation state of oxygen in H₂O₂ changes from −1 to −2 (in KOH), meaning H₂O₂ gains electrons and acts as an oxidising agent. Iodide (I⁻) is oxidised to I₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In reactions with Cl₂, KMnO₄, and O₃, H₂O₂ acts as a reducing agent because it is oxidised to O₂ (oxygen goes from −1 in H₂O₂ to 0 in O₂). Only with KI does H₂O₂ accept electrons and act as the oxidising agent.

questions.question_text: The industrial method for manufacturing H₂O₂ is the:
questions.explanation_correct: H₂O₂ is manufactured industrially by the anthraquinone auto-oxidation process. 2-Ethylanthraquinone is hydrogenated using H₂ with a Pd catalyst to form 2-ethylanthrahydroquinone, which is then oxidised by air (O₂) to regenerate the anthraquinone and produce H₂O₂. The anthraquinone acts as a recyclable carrier.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Contact process is for H₂SO₄ manufacture. The Haber process produces NH₃. The Ostwald process converts NH₃ to HNO₃. Only the anthraquinone auto-oxidation process is used for large-scale H₂O₂ production.

questions.question_text: The decomposition of H₂O₂ is catalysed by:
questions.explanation_correct: MnO₂ (manganese dioxide) is a well-known catalyst for the decomposition of H₂O₂: 2H₂O₂ →(MnO₂) 2H₂O + O₂↑. Other catalysts include finely divided platinum, gold, and the enzyme catalase found in biological systems. The decomposition is exothermic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NaCl, CaCO₃, and SiO₂ are not effective catalysts for H₂O₂ decomposition. MnO₂ provides an alternative reaction pathway with lower activation energy, making it an efficient catalyst for this reaction.

questions.question_text: What does '20-volume' hydrogen peroxide mean?

options.text: 1 mL of this solution produces 20 mL of O₂ at STP on complete decomposition
20 mL of this solution is needed to produce 1 mL of O₂
It has a molecular volume of 20 cm³

questions.explanation_correct: The 'volume strength' of H₂O₂ indicates the number of volumes (mL) of oxygen gas (at STP) that can be liberated from one volume (mL) of the H₂O₂ solution upon complete decomposition: 2H₂O₂ → 2H₂O + O₂. So '20-volume H₂O₂' means 1 mL of the solution yields 20 mL of O₂ at STP.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Volume strength is not the same as percentage by mass. 20-volume H₂O₂ corresponds to approximately 6.1% w/v H₂O₂. It does not mean 20 mL of solution is needed per mL of O₂ — that would be the inverse. Molecular volume is a different concept entirely.

questions.question_text: H₂O₂ acts as a reducing agent when it reacts with acidified KMnO₄. Which observation confirms this?

options.text: The purple colour of KMnO₄ is decolourised and O₂ gas is evolved
A brown precipitate of MnO₂ is formed
The solution turns green due to formation of K₂MnO₄
H₂ gas is liberated with effervescence

questions.explanation_correct: When H₂O₂ is added to acidified KMnO₄, it acts as a reducing agent: 5H₂O₂ + 2KMnO₄ + 3H₂SO₄ → K₂SO₄ + 2MnSO₄ + 8H₂O + 5O₂. The purple colour of MnO₄⁻ disappears as Mn(VII) is reduced to colourless Mn²⁺, and O₂ gas is evolved (oxygen in H₂O₂ goes from −1 to 0). This reaction is used in volumetric estimation of H₂O₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In acidic medium, MnO₄⁻ is reduced to Mn²⁺ (colourless), not MnO₂ (which forms in neutral medium) or MnO₄²⁻ (green, which forms in strongly alkaline medium). H₂ gas is not produced — the H₂O₂ is oxidised to O₂, confirming it acts as a reducing agent.

questions.question_text: H₂O₂ is stored in dark-coloured wax-lined glass bottles because:

options.text: It reacts with transparent glass to form silicic acid
Light and rough surfaces catalyse its decomposition into water and oxygen
It evaporates rapidly in transparent containers
It reacts with atmospheric CO₂ in the presence of light

questions.explanation_correct: H₂O₂ decomposes slowly into H₂O and O₂: 2H₂O₂ → 2H₂O + O₂. This decomposition is accelerated by light (photodecomposition), heat, dust particles, and rough surfaces (which act as heterogeneous catalysts). Dark-coloured bottles prevent light exposure, and wax lining provides a smooth surface to minimise catalytic decomposition. Small amounts of stabilisers like acetanilide or phosphoric acid are often added.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₂O₂ does not react with glass or atmospheric CO₂. It does not evaporate rapidly (its vapour pressure is low). The primary concern is its decomposition, which is catalysed by light, rough surfaces, metallic impurities, and MnO₂ dust. Dark, smooth-walled containers minimise these effects.

questions.question_text: In H₂O₂, the oxidation state of oxygen is:
questions.explanation_correct: In H₂O₂, each hydrogen has oxidation state +1. For the molecule to be electrically neutral: 2(+1) + 2(x) = 0, giving x = −1. Each oxygen atom has an oxidation state of −1, which is intermediate between 0 (in O₂) and −2 (in H₂O). This unusual oxidation state allows H₂O₂ to act as both an oxidising agent (O goes from −1 to −2) and a reducing agent (O goes from −1 to 0).
questions.explanation_incorrect: −2 is the oxidation state of oxygen in most compounds (H₂O, oxides) but not in peroxides. 0 is the oxidation state in elemental O₂. +1 would apply to OF₂ (oxygen difluoride). In peroxides like H₂O₂, Na₂O₂, and BaO₂, oxygen has the characteristic oxidation state of −1.

questions.question_text:
H₂O₂ can act as both oxidising and reducing agent. In which of the following pairs does it act as a reducing agent in the first reaction and an oxidising agent in the second?
(I) H₂O₂ + Cl₂ → 2HCl + O₂
(II) H₂O₂ + 2KI → 2KOH + I₂

options.text: Reducing agent in (I), oxidising agent in (II)
Oxidising agent in (I), reducing agent in (II)

questions.explanation_correct: In reaction (I): H₂O₂ + Cl₂ → 2HCl + O₂. Oxygen goes from −1 in H₂O₂ to 0 in O₂ (oxidised), so H₂O₂ acts as a reducing agent. In reaction (II): H₂O₂ + 2KI → 2KOH + I₂. Oxygen goes from −1 in H₂O₂ to −2 in KOH (reduced), so H₂O₂ acts as an oxidising agent. It oxidises I⁻ to I₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The oxidation state change of oxygen determines the role: when O goes from −1 to 0 (loses electrons), H₂O₂ is a reducing agent; when O goes from −1 to −2 (gains electrons), H₂O₂ is an oxidising agent. Reaction (I) shows reduction (reducing agent) and reaction (II) shows oxidation (oxidising agent) roles.

questions.question_text: The O–O bond length in H₂O₂ (148 pm) is intermediate between that in O₂ (121 pm) and O₂²⁻ (149 pm). The correct bond order in H₂O₂ is:
questions.explanation_correct: In H₂O₂, the two oxygen atoms are connected by a single covalent bond (O–O), with each oxygen also bonded to one hydrogen and having two lone pairs. The bond order is 1. The O–O single bond length (148 pm) is close to that of the peroxide ion O₂²⁻ (149 pm), which also has bond order 1. This is longer than the O=O double bond in O₂ (121 pm, bond order 2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bond order 2 corresponds to O₂ (double bond, 121 pm). Bond order 1.5 corresponds to O₂⁻ (superoxide ion, ~133 pm). Bond order 0.5 would give an even longer, weaker bond. The bond length of 148 pm in H₂O₂ is consistent with a single bond (bond order 1).

questions.question_text: When H₂O₂ is added to an acidified solution of potassium dichromate (K₂Cr₂O₇), the following is observed:

options.text: The orange colour deepens and no gas is evolved
A deep blue colour of CrO₅ is initially produced, which decomposes to give a green solution
A yellow precipitate of CrO₃ is formed
A violet colour develops due to formation of Cr₂O₃

questions.explanation_correct: When H₂O₂ is added to acidified K₂Cr₂O₇, an unstable deep blue chromium pentoxide (CrO₅) is initially formed: Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 4H₂O₂ + 2H⁺ → 2CrO₅ + 5H₂O. CrO₅ has the structure CrO(O₂)₂ with two peroxo linkages. This blue colour quickly fades as CrO₅ decomposes in acidic medium to give green Cr³⁺ ions: 2CrO₅ + 6H⁺ → 2Cr³⁺ + 5O₂ + 3H₂O. This is a characteristic test for H₂O₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A yellow precipitate of CrO₃ is not formed in this reaction. The diagnostic observation is the transient deep blue colour of CrO₅ (chromium pentoxide), followed by decomposition to a green solution containing Cr³⁺. The blue CrO₅ can be stabilised by extracting it into ether.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen is used in the Haber process. The balanced equation for the Haber process is:

options.text: N₂ + 2H₂ → N₂H₄ (at high pressure, Fe catalyst)
N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃ (at 450–500°C, 200 atm, Fe catalyst with Mo promoter)
N₂ + H₂ → 2NH (at room temperature, Pt catalyst)

questions.explanation_correct: The Haber process synthesises ammonia: N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g). Conditions: temperature 450–500°C, pressure ~200 atm, iron catalyst with molybdenum as promoter. The reaction is reversible and exothermic (ΔH = −92.4 kJ/mol). High pressure favours product formation (Le Chatelier's principle), while moderate temperature balances rate and equilibrium yield.
questions.explanation_incorrect: N₂H₄ (hydrazine) is not the product of the Haber process. The stoichiometry N₂ + H₂ → 2NH and the formula N₂H₃ do not correspond to any real reaction or stable product. V₂O₅ is the catalyst for the Contact process (SO₃ production), not ammonia synthesis. The Haber process specifically produces NH₃.

questions.question_text: The ion-exchange method for water softening uses a cation-exchange resin (RNa₂). The resin can be regenerated by:

options.text: Passing dilute HCl through the exhausted resin
Passing concentrated NaCl (brine) solution through the exhausted resin
Washing the resin with distilled water

questions.explanation_correct: After the cation-exchange resin is exhausted (all Na⁺ replaced by Ca²⁺/Mg²⁺: Na₂R + Ca²⁺ → CaR + 2Na⁺), it is regenerated by passing concentrated NaCl (brine) solution through it. The high concentration of Na⁺ drives the reverse reaction: CaR + 2NaCl → Na₂R + CaCl₂. The Ca²⁺ ions are washed away, and the resin is recharged with Na⁺.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dilute HCl would convert the resin to its H⁺ form, not Na⁺ form (this is used for deionisation resins, not softening). Heating to 500°C would destroy the organic resin. Distilled water alone cannot displace Ca²⁺ from the resin. Brine (concentrated NaCl) is the standard regenerant for sodium-form cation exchangers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements does NOT form a stable ionic hydride?
questions.explanation_correct: Beryllium does not form a stable ionic hydride. Due to its very small size and high charge density (high polarising power), BeH₂ is a covalent polymeric hydride rather than an ionic one. Li, Ca, and Ba, being larger with lower charge densities, form true ionic hydrides (LiH, CaH₂, BaH₂) containing discrete H⁻ ions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Li forms LiH (ionic), Ca forms CaH₂ (ionic), and Ba forms BaH₂ (ionic). All three are s-block metals large enough to form genuine ionic hydrides. Only beryllium, due to its exceptionally small atomic radius and high ionisation energy, forms a covalent (polymeric) hydride.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a use of hydrogen peroxide?

options.text: As a dehydrating agent in organic reactions
As an antiseptic and bleaching agent
As a catalyst in the Haber process
As a reducing agent in the thermite reaction

questions.explanation_correct: H₂O₂ is widely used as an antiseptic (for wound cleaning, typically 3% solution), as a bleaching agent for hair, textiles, paper pulp, and ivory (it bleaches by oxidation without leaving residue). Concentrated H₂O₂ (90%) is used as a rocket propellant (HTP — High Test Peroxide). It is also used in pollution control for treating industrial effluents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₂O₂ is an oxidising/reducing agent, not a dehydrating agent (that role belongs to conc. H₂SO₄ or P₂O₅). The catalyst in the Haber process is iron with molybdenum promoter, not H₂O₂. The thermite reaction uses Al and Fe₂O₃, not H₂O₂.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following industrial processes:
(I) Hydrogenation of vegetable oils using Ni catalyst
(II) Synthesis of methanol: CO + 2H₂ → CH₃OH
(III) Oxy-hydrogen flame for welding (>2000°C)
In which of these is dihydrogen used?
questions.explanation_correct: Dihydrogen is used in all three processes: (I) Hydrogenation of vegetable oils (converting C=C double bonds to C–C single bonds using H₂ and Ni catalyst at 473 K to produce vanaspati ghee). (II) Methanol synthesis from syngas (CO + 2H₂ → CH₃OH using ZnO-Cr₂O₃ catalyst). (III) Oxy-hydrogen torch (H₂ burned in O₂ to produce temperatures >2000°C for cutting/welding metals).
questions.explanation_incorrect: All three processes require dihydrogen. Hydrogenation uses H₂ to saturate oils. Methanol synthesis uses H₂ with CO. The oxy-hydrogen flame uses the combustion of H₂ in pure O₂. None of these processes can operate without dihydrogen.

questions.question_text: When soap is used with hard water, the following happens:

options.text: A rich lather is formed immediately
Scum (insoluble calcium/magnesium stearate) is formed, wasting soap
The soap dissolves the Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ ions completely

questions.explanation_correct: When soap (sodium stearate, C₁₇H₃₅COONa) is used with hard water, it reacts with Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ ions to form insoluble calcium stearate (C₁₇H₃₅COO)₂Ca and magnesium stearate: 2C₁₇H₃₅COONa + Ca²⁺ → (C₁₇H₃₅COO)₂Ca↓ + 2Na⁺. This curdy white precipitate (scum) wastes soap and prevents lather formation until all Ca²⁺/Mg²⁺ is consumed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hard water does not allow soap to lather easily because the Ca²⁺/Mg²⁺ ions first react with soap to form scum. The soap does not dissolve or remove the ions — it gets consumed. The water does not become softer; rather, soap is wasted until the hardness-causing ions are precipitated.

questions.question_text: H₂O₂ can be detected by adding it to an acidified solution containing Ti⁴⁺ ions. The observation is:

options.text: A white precipitate of TiO₂ is formed
An intense yellow/orange colour due to formation of pertitanic acid [TiO₂(OH)₂] or titanium peroxide
A green colour due to reduction of Ti⁴⁺ to Ti³⁺

questions.explanation_correct: The reaction of H₂O₂ with Ti⁴⁺ ions in acidic solution produces a characteristic yellow/orange-coloured titanium peroxide complex (pertitanic acid): Ti⁴⁺ + H₂O₂ + 2H₂O → H₂TiO₄ (or TiO₂·xH₂O₂ complex). This is a highly sensitive and specific colorimetric test for detecting H₂O₂, even in very dilute solutions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The test does not produce a white precipitate, green colour, or chlorine gas. The diagnostic result is a yellow-orange coloration due to the titanium-peroxo complex. This reaction is used in quantitative analysis of H₂O₂ via spectrophotometry.
